alert.note: Alert for Lincoln (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 26 at 12:33PM MDT by NWS Riverton
info.description: ...WARMING TEMPERATURES WILL RESULT IN INCREASED SNOW MELT AND POTENTIAL FLOODING... Temperatures will increase through the weekend, resulting in increased snow melt in lower elevations. High temperatures for lower elevations are expected to be in the middle to upper 50s to near 60 this weekend with low temperatures only dropping to near freezing. These warm temperatures could result in significant low land snow melt. Temperatures remaining near or even above freezing overnight will further exasperate snow melt rates. Melted snow will likely run off into local streams and rivers, and could cause some minor river flooding along parts of the Bear River and its tributaries. While most of the flooding potential will be as a result of runoff in low elevations, snowmelt in the foothills will also increase flow on small creeks and streams. Ice jam flooding is also possible on streams and rivers that are still ice covered. Now would be the time to clear snow, ice, and debris from culverts and other flow paths to allow runoff to flow away from buildings and other vulnerable infrastructure. This could include moving deep snow away from the foundations of buildings, moving equipment, and moving livestock out of poorly drained or low lying areas. Stay tuned for the latest river forecasts and remember, if you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around don`t drown, you never know what road conditions are hidden under the water.
